name: Southern Lesser Galago
description: It has large brown eyes, relatively long and wide ears, and dense light gray-brown fur. It can rotate its head 180 degrees. Males and females look alike, with males slightly heavier.
spread_note: Africa from South Africa to Tanzania
proportions: Body length 14–17 cm; tail length 11–28 cm; weight 142–255 g
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 121–124 days and bear 1–2 young
attractions: Southern lesser galagos live in small family groups of several females and their young. Males are solitary, defending territories encompassing the home ranges of multiple female groups. They sleep during the day, often in hollow acacia trunks or other trees. At night, they forage individually. Females give birth and raise young in nests high in trees—either building their own or using abandoned bird nests or tree hollows.
breeding: Southern lesser galagos arrived at Prague Zoo in early 2014.
